009package imagingbook.core.resource;
010
011import java.io.File;
012import java.io.InputStream;
013import java.net.URL;
014
015/**
016 * <p>
017 * This interface is supposed to be implemented by some enum class that
018 * specifies the root of a resource tree. The following example defines
019 * such an enum type that refers to three images. The path relative 
020 * to the location of the enum class itself must be specified
021 * and images must be stored there.
022 * The enum type must define an appropriate constructor and implement
023 * method {@link #getRelativePath()}:
024 * </p>
025
026 * <pre>
027 * public enum MyImages implements NamedResource {
028 *      image1("image1.tif"),
029 *      image2("image2.png"),
030 *      image3("jpegs/image3.jpg");
031 * 
032 *      // field to associate relative resource path
033 *      private final String relPath;
034 * 
035 *      &#64;Override
036 *      public String getRelativePath() {
037 *              return relPath;
038 *      }
039 * 
040 *      // constructor
041 *      MyImages(String relPath) {
042 *              this.relPath = relPath;
043 *      }
044 * }</pre>
045 * <p>
046 * Resources are then only referenced by their enum-name, for example,
047 * </p>
048 * <pre>
049 * URI uri = MyImages.image1.getURI();
050 * ImagePlus im = IJ.openImage(uri.toString());
051 * </pre>
052 * <p>
053 * The benefit of using a named resource (over specifying resources by path strings) 
054 * is that the resource is guaranteed to exist at compile time (this is assured
055 * by validating the existence of all named resources in the test phase) and can be retrieved
056 * even if located inside a JAR file.
057 *
058 * </p>
059 * @author WB
060 * @version 2022/04/12
061 */
062public interface NamedResource {
063        
064        public String getRelativePath();
065        
066        public default URL getURL() {
067                Class<?> clazz = this.getClass();
068                return clazz.getResource(this.getRelativePath());
069        }
070        
071//      @Deprecated
072//      public default URI getURI() {
073//              try {
074//                      return getURL().toURI();
075//              } catch (URISyntaxException e) {
076//                      return null;
077//              }
078//      }
079        
080//      /**
081//       * Returns the {@link Path} to the associated resource object.
082//       * @return the resource's {@link Path} 
083//       */
084//      @Deprecated
085//      public default Path getPath() {
086//              //return toPath(this.getURI());
087//              return Paths.get(getURI());
088//      }
089        
090//      public default URI getURI() {
091//              Class<?> clazz = this.getClass();
092//              String resourceName = getRelativePath();
093//              Objects.requireNonNull(resourceName);
094//              URI uri = null;
095//              if (this.isInsideJar()) {       // (classInsideJar(clazz))
096//                      String classPath = clazz.getProtectionDomain().getCodeSource().getLocation().getFile();
097//                      //String packagePath = clazz.getPackage().getName().replace('.', File.separatorChar);
098//                      String packagePath = clazz.getPackage().getName().replace('.', '/');
099//                      String compPath = "jar:file:" + classPath + "!/" + packagePath + "/" + resourceName;
100//                      try {
101//                              uri = new URI(compPath);
102//                      } catch (URISyntaxException e) {
103//                              throw new RuntimeException(e.toString());
104//                      }       
105//              }
106//              else {  // regular file path
107//                      try {
108//                              URL url = clazz.getResource(resourceName);
109//                              if (url != null) {
110//                                      uri = url.toURI();
111//                              }
112//                      } catch (URISyntaxException e) {
113//                              //do nothing, just return null
114//                      }
115//              }
116//              return uri;
117//      }
118        
119//      /**
120//       * Converts an {@link URI} to a {@link Path} for objects that are either
121//       * in the file system or inside a JAR file.
122//       * 
123//       * @param uri the specified {@link URI}
124//       * @return the associated {@link Path}
125//       */
126//      public static Path toPath(URI uri) {
127//              Path path = null;
128//              String scheme = uri.getScheme();
129//              switch (scheme) {
130//              case "jar":     {       // resource inside JAR file
131//                      FileSystem fs = null;
132//                      try { // check if this FileSystem already exists 
133//                              fs = FileSystems.getFileSystem(uri);
134//                      } catch (FileSystemNotFoundException e) {
135//                              // that's OK to happen, the file system is not created automatically
136//                      }
137//                      
138//                      if (fs == null) {       // must not create the file system twice
139//                              try {
140//                                      Map<String, Object> map = Collections.emptyMap();
141//                                      fs = FileSystems.newFileSystem(uri, map);       // FileSystems.newFileSystem(uri, Collections.<String, Object>emptyMap());
142//                              } catch (IOException e) {
143//                                      throw new RuntimeException(e.toString());
144//                              }
145//                      }
146//                      
147//                      String ssp = uri.getSchemeSpecificPart();
148//                      int startIdx = ssp.lastIndexOf('!');
149//                      String inJarPath = ssp.substring(startIdx + 1);  // in-Jar path (after the last '!')
150//                      path = fs.getPath(inJarPath);
151//                      break;
152//              }
153//              case "file": {  // resource in ordinary file system
154//                      path = Paths.get(uri);
155//                      break;
156//              }
157//              default:
158//                      throw new IllegalArgumentException("Cannot handle this URI type: " + scheme);
159//              }
160//              return path;
161//      }
162        
163        public default boolean isInsideJar() {
164                URL url = getClass().getProtectionDomain().getCodeSource().getLocation();
165                String path = url.getPath();
166                File file = new File(path);
167                return file.isFile();
168        }
169
170//      static boolean classInsideJar(Class<?> clazz) {
171//      URL url = clazz.getProtectionDomain().getCodeSource().getLocation();
172//      String path = url.getPath();
173//      File file = new File(path);
174//      return file.isFile();
175//}
176        
177        /**
178         * Returns an {@link InputStream} for reading from this resource.
179         * See also {@link Class#getResourceAsStream(String)}.
180         * @return an {@link InputStream} for this resource
181         */
182        public default InputStream getStream() {
183                return getClass().getResourceAsStream(getRelativePath());
184        }
185
186}
